questions.stem: How is authority to act obtained for a duty solicitor scheme call?

options.text: The DSCC automatically assigns you and you must attend
The DSCC contacts you, you confirm availability, and authority is granted via call-back
You contact the police station directly and they grant authority
Authority is granted automatically when you are on the duty solicitor rota

questions.explanation: Authority to act under the duty solicitor scheme is obtained through the DSCC (Defence Solicitor Call Centre). The DSCC contacts you, you confirm availability, and authority is granted via the call-back process. You cannot simply attend without DSCC authorisation.

questions.stem: What is the main difference between duty solicitor scheme work and own-client work in terms of authority to act?

options.text: Duty solicitor work requires DSCC call-back; own-client work requires direct client instruction
Both require DSCC authorisation
Own-client work requires police station approval
There is no difference in how authority is obtained

questions.explanation: Duty solicitor scheme work requires DSCC call-back and authorisation. Own-client work occurs when a client directly instructs you (or your firm), and you attend without needing DSCC authorisation. However, probationary representatives have restrictions on own-client work.

references.cite: Police Station Register Arrangements 2025 — authority to act
Police Station Register Arrangements 2025 — probationary period

questions.stem: A probationary PSR receives a DSCC call. They confirm availability and attend. What must they ensure about their work?

options.text: They can work independently without supervision
They must be supervised and cannot do own-client work during probationary period
They can do own-client work if the client requests it
They only need supervision for complex cases

questions.explanation: Probationary PSRs must work under supervision and are restricted from own-client work during the 12-month probationary period. They can work on duty solicitor scheme cases with proper supervision, but cannot take on own-client instructions until they complete probationary requirements.

questions.stem: What information should you obtain from the DSCC during the initial call-back to establish authority to act?

options.text: Only the police station name and address
Client name, offence, custody location, and any urgent issues
The full case file and evidence
Only confirmation that you are assigned

questions.explanation: During the DSCC call-back, you should gather key information: client name, alleged offence, custody location, and any urgent issues (e.g., vulnerability, time limits, interview timing). This helps you prepare and identify immediate concerns. You won't receive the full case file at this stage.

questions.stem: A client calls your firm directly and asks you to attend the police station. You are a probationary PSR. What should you do?

options.text: Attend immediately as the client has instructed you directly
Explain you cannot take own-client work during probationary period and refer to DSCC or a qualified supervisor
Attend but ensure a supervisor reviews your work afterwards
Only attend if the offence is minor

questions.explanation: Probationary PSRs are restricted from own-client work. If a client calls directly, you must explain the restriction and either refer them to the DSCC (for duty solicitor scheme) or to a qualified supervisor who can take the instruction. You cannot simply attend and have work reviewed later—the restriction is on taking the instruction itself.
